WorkItem.ClosedComment: As you've discovered, the setValueExplicit() was created to provide a solution for precisely this situation
WorkItem.Description:
Consider the following code:
$objWorkSheetNew->getStyle("A1")->getNumberFormat()->setFormatCode(PHPExcel_Style_NumberFormat::FORMAT_TEXT);
$objWorkSheetNew->getCell("A1")->setValue('000002');
I expect that to display as "000002". However, it gets displayed as "2". The reason is that the cell contains a value of "2" and not of "000002".
I can use $objWorkSheetNew->getStyle("A1")->getNumberFormat()->setFormatCode('000000') to force padding on this value, but that's not the same. The value still remains as "2", it just displays as "000002".
I'm originally using a variable there, of course. So I tried casting that to a string, but the problem remains. So, it seems that setValue always changes that "stringy number" to a number and there is no way to reverse it.
Â 
What I expect is that if I setValue('000002') this should be inserted as such and not converted to a number without leading zeros.
Also, concerning setFormatCode('000000') I find that if I select Format Cell in Excel it shows a Format of Special with locale Chinese(PRC). Which looks weird, if not wrong. I think it should rather be Custom '000000'.
WorkItem.Summary: setValue strips leading zeros from strings that resemble numbers

Comments.Message: I have finally found the correct method it seems. setValueExplicit with PHPExcel_Cell_DataType::TYPE_STRING comes to the rescue. It wasn't obvious from the Excel properties one could also set a datatype. This report can get closed.
